data.title: Test new DebugConfigurationProvider for node-debug
data.body:
Test for #33835:

Complexity: 3

- [x] Windows - @dbaeumer 
- [x] OS X - @octref 
- [x] Linux - @chrmarti 

The node-debug extension has been updated to use the new `DebugConfigurationProvider` (that had been introduced in the last milestone).

Verification:

for node-debug (both legacy and inspector protocol) make sure that:
- default launch config is generated if no launch.config is present and the gear button is pressed
- the default launch config's `program` attribute is correctly initialized from the `main` attribute of the package.json or its `start` script.
- the generated launch.json has an `outFiles` attributes if one of the open documents contains TypeScript
- debug sessions correctly start when a launch.json is present
- debug sessions correctly start when no launch.json is present but a JavaScript is open in the active editor
- debug sessions correctly start in the no-folder case when a JavaScript file is open in the active editor.

data.title: Test build and watch tasks for tsconfig
data.body:
Test #33863

**Size** 1

**OS**
- [x] Linux - @aeschli 
- [x] Mac - @kieferrm 
- [x] Windows - @dbaeumer 

**Overview**
Automatic task detection should now create both a build and a watch task for every `tsconfig` in a workspace. 

**Testing**
- Open a workspace with a tsconfig
- Ensure both a build and watch task for it show up in the build menu
- Try configuring the watch task as the default build task
- Create multiple tsconfigs in the workspace and ensure these also show up

data.title: Smoke test on Windows shares the same IPC handles
data.body: The smoke test runs all share the same IPC handles on Windows because the named pipes are not scoped to the `user-data-dir`...

data.title: Test: Region folding markers
data.body:
Tests #12146

Complexity 3

- [x]  @auchenberg 
- [x] @sandy081 

Folding now supports region markers. Markers are defined by the language in the language configuration. The following languages currently have markers defined:

- TypeScript/JavaScript:  `//#region` and `//#endregion`  and `//region` and `//endregion`
- C#: `#region` and `#endregion`
- C/C++: `#pragma region` and `#pragma endregion`
- F#: `//#region` and `//#endregion`
- Powershell: `#region` and `#endregion`
- VB: `#Region` and `#End Region`

Region markers are case sensitive.

- test that the region folding works
- test edge cases: Missing start or end patterns, nested regions
- test the snippets for the folding markers

data.title: Smoke test on macOS hits socket file path limit issue
data.body:
I swear we seem to hit every single exoteric issue with this smoke test.

The smoke test creates brand new user-data-dir folders in TEMP. In macOS, TEMP is usually a huge path. The communication sockets live inside user-data-dir. UNIX sockets have a [file path length limit](https://serverfault.com/questions/641347/check-if-a-path-exceeds-maximum-for-unix-domain-socket). So the sockets are simply cut. This surfaces as incredibly random and unconnected issues within the smoke test.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22350/30829079-11d8ff2c-a240-11e7-85c7-68d0958a05e1.png)

This took me **way** too long to find out.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (f7962f0682a76516df51de4856f8ccc5d8ad578a, 2017-09-20T05:24:33.599Z)

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version

vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.18
perforce|sle|2.2.1
tslint-tmp-multiroot-compat|sqs|0.17.0
autoimport|ste|1.2.2


Trying to launch with attached debugger via Code.
Not sure if it is even possible/feasible to so do from a single window - didn't bother trying.  Attempting to open two vscode windows for side by side debugging of two submodules/executables of a larger project.
launch and debug parameters for both are stored in the workspace's launch.cfg

Opening a new vscode window, then trying to reopen the same workspace results in the original workspace being pushed to front, leaving the new vscode in the 'no-open-workspace' state


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Open workspace
2.Open new window
3. open the same workspace (via recent or direct to file)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Tests #3353.

Test that folding in languages adhering to the [off-side rule](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Off-side_rule):
Python, Yaml, Pug, Markdown, Clojure, Coffescript, FSharp.

data.title: Allow customizable aliases for each terminal instance
data.body:
If I 3 terminal instances running, currently they are titled, "1: Bash", "2: Bash, "3:Bash".

It would be nice if we could each instance a customizable alias/title to help us remember what task each instance is doing.

data.title: Git Precommit check is not showing error when the added file is saved [ vscode contribution issue ]

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
While contributing to vscode, I added some changes on the code and I while doing a commit the precommit check is errored out and I edited and saved the file , then precommit is working , it should not .

- VSCode Version:
1.16.1

- OS Version:
Ubuntu 16

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Clone vscode repo
2. Try adding some code which makes tslint error and do a commit on the file  , the pre-commit check will show error 
3. Save the file and do commit (without adding the file), the commit will work , It should not because ( the changes won't be added but the pre-commit script is allowing that )

Reproduces without extensions: Nothing to do with extensions

Could a recall buffer / typeahead feature be added to the input box in the SEARCH tool??

data.title: Strange behaviour for cursor movement in find widget
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

I like to use alt+j/alt+l for cursor movement, so i define the following keybinding:
```
,{
    "key": "alt+l", // or "alt+j"
    "command": "cursorRight",
    "when": "editorFocus && findInputFocussed && findWidgetVisible"
}
```

but when i
1. open find widget
2. type alt+l

Two strange behaviours occur:
-> cursor disappear
-> even though widget is focussed, cursor movement is done in the editor.

I've chosed the same "when" clause of alt+up / alt+down used in find history commands.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Add 'Collapse All' to Explorer panel

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Now that the Explorer panel allows for extensions to add their own items, it can get quite cluttered, showing for example, open files, project files, code outline, git log, bookmarks, Docker containers, etc, etc.

It would be helpful to have a Collapse All button at the top of this list (or wherever is deemed appropriate), along with Collapse Other buttons on each section, to quickly de-clutter this view.

data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

Operating System: Linux Mint.

1. Open terminal in VSCode
2. cd to some directory (different from the default/home directory)
3. Restart vscode
4. Terminal is restored but the current directory is not same as the one prior to restart

#Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Keep "find" and "search" in sync
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1 (1.16.1)
- OS Version: OS X

Steps to Reproduce:

1. cmd+shift+f to do a global search (type in something that will occur multiple times in a file)
2. Click into a result to open the file
3. cmd+g to "find next" and it doesn't work because "find" is independent of "search"

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Other editors like Sublime Text keep these values in sync (because they re-use the same UI). It'd be amazing if there was a way to accomplish this even if via an extension. 
If an extension is possible I can look into it. (not familiar with the APIs yet)

data.title: Default Git SCM
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.16.1 - OS Version: OSX Sierra 10.12.6 Have recently updated VS code, to find that the inbuilt git SCM has disappeared. Different SCM extensions display as normal, but once removed does not display the default. Command Pallet does not allow running "Switch SCM", "Disable SCM", "Disable Preview SCM" Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open VSCode on a single project 2. Go to SCM tab 2. Observe that the default Git provider is a non-option Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: API for hierarchical document symbol data
data.body:
In order to support a real outline view (#5605) and a breadcrumb bar (#9418, #31162) we need better document symbol information. Today, the API doesn't allow providers to return tree data and it also doesn't spec what the ranges of symbols should be. Some language extensions make the range be the whole symbol range, some make it the identifier range. It needs a new or refined API to support hierarchies, I see two options

* allow a tree of `SymbolInformation`-objects, e.g. add an optional `children`-property. 
* have two range-objects on `SymbolInformation`-objects, one being the whole range and one being the identifier range. While this looks counter intuitive and worst than having tree-style-data it makes merging of different data sets from different providers easy.

data.title: Test new symbolic view column
data.body:
Test for: #27408
Complexity: 1

- [x] Any OS - @bpasero 

We have a new `ViewColumn` which isn't denoting one of the column 1, 2, or 3 but is a indirection, denoting the current active column. Test that

* is works
* is documented properly
* it works when there no editor
* it works when the active column isn't an ap-ish editor but an image or extension preview

data.title: Test snippet transform
data.body:
Test for: #6920
Complexity: 3

- [x] macOS - @weinand 
- [x] Windows - @ramya-rao-a 

Snippet transformation allow you to modify the value of a variable before inserting it. Refer to the documentation about all details: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/editor/contrib/snippet/browser/snippet.md#L31. In short, transforms are four values: (1) the variable to transform, (2) the regex that describes the transform, (3) a replace string that is inserted, (4) regex options. Also note that the syntax is "given" by Textmate, so just make sure we support what we have promised.

Test that 
* you upper-case (lower-case, capitalise) things, e.g with `${SOME_VAR/(.*)/${1:/upcase}/g}`
* you can remove the suffix when using the `TM_FILENAME` variable, e.g. make it insert `foo` instead of `foo.txt`
* you can generate a (Java/C#) constructor from a filename
* get creative, check the doc linked above is good
